ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a deeper understanding of existentialism, phenomenology, and the unique political situation of Soviet and post-Soviet eastern europe.

I learned all about philosophers and their most important texts of the 19th century. I learned how to discuss different thinkers through the lens of history. Learned to think critically about different philosophical ideas of dissent.
I learnt so much about eastern european history! and how to read very dense texts in continental philosophy, e.g. patoka. My favourite theme was responsibility.

I learned a lot about philosophy of dissent in Eastern in Central Europe, as the title of the course might suggest. I also learned a bit more about how to write a paper about philosophy, something I did not have much experience with.
Knowledge regarding the intellectual history of the 1945-1989 period, knowledge of eastern european philosophy, revisionist Marxism and Central European history in the post-war era
I learned the skills of close reading and argumentative writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
No weaknesses, if only more office hours (although I understand that this was an exceptional semester and Professor Shore had a lot on her mind). 

This course has so many strengths. Professor Shore is brilliant. She is an engaging seminar leader. The readings are dense but rich and rewarding. The weekly conversations are poignant and relevant to modern day life. I could go on.
I loved how Professor Shore guides the class. She is brilliant and I would prefer she speak for 70% of the class!

strengths: seminar discussion was lovely, Prof. Shore is wonderful and cares a lot about her students, creates such a nice environment to learn in.  readings are really interesting and presentations help us digest the texts very well
Strengths: Marci Shore. She is brilliant and wonderful. Also, the readings are, for the most part, great. I absolutely loved reading and discussing most of them.

strengths:
good mix of philosophy and history (though mostly philosophy)
good readings
engaging discussions
The class had both discussions and a lecture element
Having presenters was a good idea
The readings were chosen very thoughtfully and the professor was very informed. It could be improved by making the discussions more structured.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. If you have taken European Intellectual History Since Nietzsche and find yourself craving more of Marci Shore, this is the class to take. It will continue the dialogue started by the Marxist-Hegelians and the existentialists into the 21st century in fascinating ways.
Yes. Having the opportunity to be in a seminar with Professor Shore is incredible.

Highly recommend! A fantastic introduction to phenomenology (very cool, coming from someone who almost exclusively studied ancient phil), interesting developments in political, philosophical, and religious contexts, and the course compares and contrasts thinkers of the era so well
Yes. Wonderful course

absolutely. eastern european dissidents have so much to teach us. if you are at all interested in history, or philosophy, prof. shores style of intellectual history is a fascinating intersection between these subjects.
I would absolutely recommend this course
Yes, for anyone interested in intellectual history of the postwar period, especially inspired by Heidegger and Husserl
I would. It is extensive and challenging.
